page.title: 08Wormleighton Passing of Time
page.content: One tenant in the cottages in Wormleighton was born and brought up in the village. He is now retired and gave us a picture of changes in farming. Horses were used to draw ploughs and the usual hours of work per week were fifty in winter and fiftytwo in summer. Payment was ten shillings per week plus threepence per hour overtime. Transport was limited to cycling or walking in the village but there was more public transport than today. Buses went to Leamington Spa and Banbury two days per week. Now the farmer can cope with one or two workers and whereas a typical good harvest was one ton now it is three or four tons for the same area. On many farms corn is grown continuously with weeds and disease controlled by spraying often repeatedly.
